statement:
[**Theorem -** ]{} Let $X$ be a locally compact space and
$Y \subseteq X$ a subspace. If $Y$ is locally closed in $X$ then $Y$ is
also locally compact.

The converse of this theorem is also true with the additional assumption
that $X$ is Hausdorff.

[**Theorem 2 -**]{} Let $X$ be a and $Y \subseteq X$ a subspace. If $Y$
is locally compact then $Y$ is locally closed in $X$.
names: local compactness is hereditary for locally closed subspaces
